title: A $3.7b typo nearly sinks submarine project's credibility
text:
The Australian Financial Review understands the money actually had been provisioned for, and covers design work, equipment for the Adelaide shipyard and mobilisation of the workforce needed to build the submarines, up to 2026-27.

The Defence Department promised to publish more accurate figures.

"Defence has identified unclear labels on the presentation of the supplementary online material … as being expenditure in a single financial year. The Department will release an updated table once finalised," a statement said.

"To be clear, there have been no underestimates or budget overruns for the Future Submarine or Hunter Class programs. These programs will be funded through a series of progressive government approvals – all which are provisioned within the Defence Integrated Investment Program.

"As at 30 June 2019, expenditure on Future Submarine design and construction was $834.6 million, which included the cost of design work, the science and technology program, and operational costs."

Unwanted distraction

Opposition assistant defence minister Pat Conroy said public confidence in the government's handling of the submarine project was being undermined.

“The Future Submarine project is already running 10 years late and is cloaked in secrecy. The fact that Defence can’t even manage to accurately report on a $3.7 billion increase in the project’s budget is of real concern,” he said.

Advertisement

“Furthermore, to find out about a quadrupling of the project budget through an appendix to an annual report demonstrates that this project lacks adequate transparency."

While minor, the gaffe is another unwanted distraction for what is billed as Australia's most complex and expensive public works project.

The error in the report emerged on the eve for Senate estimates, where senior Defence officials were already facing a grilling over complaints Australian suppliers risked missing out on work.

There is also speculation the project may be running up to 18 months behind schedule, with major contracts with suppliers being signed only now, much later than envisaged.

Defence faces another headache with the submarine program with an interstate stoush over the potential relocation of deep maintenance operations for the Collins class submarine.

While Western Australia has made a strong bid to secure full-cycle dockings of the Collins class submarines – which see the boats taken out of the water for two years and cut open to undergo a significant overhaul – South Australia is resisting any move to shift the work.

Key Senator Rex Patrick has threatened the Morrison government that any move to shift full-cycle dockings, and the hundreds of jobs at ASC that go with it, would jeopardise Centre Alliance support for legislation.
description: Defence has denied it has underestimated the cost of the new submarine project, blaming a typo for the mistake.
